awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Obesity as a Natural Experiment to Investigate Bone Functional Adaptation
awd_abstract_narration:
While it is understood that bone is a dynamic, living tissue that responds to changes in the forces applied to it, researchers do not yet have a complete and detailed understanding of this response in humans. This project will compare the skeletons of individuals who were overweight and healthy-weight during life to determine the effects of increased loading and altered walking mechanics on bone microstructure. Results will help clarify the role mechanical force plays in determining bone microstructure and assess the sensitivity of bone to load alteration. Understanding changes in bone microstructure as a function of loading may help anthropologists reconstruct past behaviors from bone form and may also inform clinical understanding of conditions such as osteoporosis and osteoarthritis. Elucidating the relationship between body weight and bone microstructure may also provide forensic anthropologists new insights for identifying decedents from skeletal material. As part of this project, three female graduate students will receive diverse and intense hands-on research training in high-resolution computed tomography, image analysis, and bone microstructure analysis. In addition, the project will foster public science outreach, specifically engaging students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields.  

The theoretical basis behind the scientific understanding of bone functional adaptation is that bone tissue that experiences high levels of mechanical strain will adapt by adding bone material, while low strain levels will lead to bone resorption or reduction. The goal of this project is to test bone functional adaptation ("Wolff's Law") in humans using obesity as a natural experiment in load alteration. Results will establish if and how variation in locomotor motion (kinematics) and applied forces (kinetics) associated with obesity manifest in the trabecular structure of the human skeleton. The researchers will collect high-resolution computed tomography image stacks of bones that are part of an extremely well-documented human skeletal collection. Using novel analytical techniques and leveraging well-established image analysis, this project will quantify the patterns of trabecular bone distribution in obese and healthy-weight individuals across the human skeleton. Results will advance knowledge about trabecular bone structure in the human skeleton and its relationship to mechanical loading, produce guidelines for data collection and analysis, and generate data and software for future research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaborative effort between researchers at John Hopkins University and Texas State University. The goal of the study was to explore the influence of obesity related to increased loading and altered walking mechanics on trabecular bone structure at major anatomical joints of the upper and lower limbs and the back. Specifically, this project examined bone functional adaptation in humans using obesity as a natural experiment in load alterations. High-resolution computed tomography imaging was conducted on ten bones per skeleton from twenty obese and twenty normal weight skeletons in a well-documented and ethically sourced skeletal collection. Novel analytical techniques were used to examine small volumes of interest below the joint surface and to compare the patterns of trabecular bone distribution and structure across the skeleton. Results demonstrate that obese individuals have greater average bone volume fraction (more overall bone) with less separation between trabeculae than non-obese individuals at lower limb joints. The pattern of highest volume location below the joint surface differs significantly between obese and nonobese in many joints reflecting differences in gait mechanics.

The knowledge gained from this study will enhance our understanding of bone functional adaptation and how it can be applied to past and present human and hominin populations. The work will be disseminated to professionals as well as the public through publications, presentations, and outreach programs. The study has and will continue to have a broad impact on society. First, the study allowed several female students to gain technological and research skills related to their area of research and that are directly transferable to many high paying industries. Second, knowledge of the response of trabecular bone to mechanical loads, especially due to obesity, will aid in understanding fracture risk factors and will guide clinicians in developing interventional therapies that could slow the progression of diseases. Likewise, the results strengthen the toolbox of methods used by forensic anthropologists and other practitioners by providing a tool for estimating body mass in unidentified individuals which is known to also affect other methods used in developing a biological profile from human skeletal remains.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Adam D Sylvester
